Casenote:

Forty year‑old male with a history of polysubstance abuse presented to the ED c/o intense pain and swelling of his right lower extremity (RLE) for the past two days. Patient used heroin two consecutive nights prior to presentation and reports falling asleep with his RLE folded underneath his body.

When he woke up in the morning, the leg was swollen and painful to touch. Patient states he could not move his leg due to severe pain. As the day progressed, patient noticed increasing pain and swelling of the leg in addition to the leg turning a blueish color. Patient then presented to the ED.

Upon arrival in the ED, pt was hypotensive, tachycardic, c/o severe pain in RLE.

On PE, the RLE below the knee was severely tender to touch and the soft tissue was very tense.

1. M62.99 — Unspecified disorder of muscle, site unspecified — Myositis; calcification and ossification of muscle; non‑traumatic ischaemic infarction of muscles (compartment syndrome); diseases of muscles caused by infectious and other diseases where the muscle disorder is the principal reason for the attendance; infections due to leprosy and syphilis as the cause of myositis are listed separately as notifiable diseases (NNDSS)

Casenote:
1. COMMUNITY-ACQUIRED PNEUMONIA
Patient: Mark Williams (Fictional)
DOB: 12/03/1967
MRN: 123456789
Date of Service: May 22, 2025
Time of Arrival: 11:30
Time of Discharge: 16:45
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 57-year-old male presents to ED with chief complaint of worsening cough, fever, and shortness of breath for 4 days. Patient reports initial symptoms began with mild fatigue and dry cough, which progressed to productive cough with yellow-green sputum. Developed fever to 102°F at home yesterday along with chills and night sweats. Reports increased shortness of breath with exertion and difficulty climbing stairs.
Denies chest pain, hemoptysis, or weight loss. No recent travel or sick contacts. Reports decreased appetite and fluid intake over past 2 days. No nausea or vomiting. Denies urinary symptoms or abdominal pain.
Past Medical History: Hypertension, hyperlipidemia, former smoker (quit 5 years ago, 20 pack-year history)
Medications: Lisinopril 10mg daily, atorvastatin 20mg daily
Social History: Retired mechanic, former smoker, occasional alcohol, lives with wife
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 132/84, HR 98, RR 22, Temp 101.8°F, O2 Sat 92% RA, 96% on 2L NC
General: Alert, oriented x4, appears mildly ill, mild respiratory distress
Physical Examination:
HEENT: No sinus tenderness, no lymphadenopathy
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
Pulmonary: Decreased breath sounds right lower lobe, crackles and dullness to percussion over right lower lobe, no wheeze
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, normal bowel sounds
Extremities: No edema, good capillary refill
Neurologic: Alert and oriented, no focal deficits
Laboratory Results:
CBC: WBC 14.2 k/μL (elevated), Hgb 13.8 g/dL, Hct 41.2%, Plt 345 k/μL
BMP: Normal except glucose 118 mg/dL
Procalcitonin: 2.8 ng/mL (elevated, suggesting bacterial infection)
Lactate: 1.8 mmol/L (normal)
Imaging:
Chest X-ray: Right lower lobe consolidation consistent with pneumonia, no pleural effusion
ASSESSMENT Community-acquired pneumonia, right lower lobe, moderate severity (CURB-65 score = 1)
PLAN
Emergency Department Treatment:
Oxygen therapy via nasal cannula
IV fluids 1L normal saline
Chest physiotherapy education
Discharge Medications:
Azithromycin 500mg - Take once daily for 5 days
Guaifenesin 400mg - Take twice daily as needed for cough
Acetaminophen 650mg - Every 6 hours as needed for fever/pain
Discharge Instructions:
Rest, increased fluid intake (8-10 glasses water daily)
Use humidifier or steam inhalation
No smoking or secondhand smoke exposure
Return to work when fever-free for 24 hours
ICD-10:
J15.9 - Unspecified bacterial pneumonia
Z87.891 - Personal history of nicotine dependence

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
11. MIGRAINE HEADACHE
Patient: Sarah Thompson (Fictional), DOB: 06/11/1985
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 39-year-old female presents with severe unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea for 6 hours. Reports similar headaches monthly, typically triggered by stress, lack of sleep, or hormonal changes. Current episode began this morning, progressively worsening despite ibuprofen and rest. Associated with nausea and one episode of vomiting. Denies visual changes, fever, or neck stiffness.
Past Medical History: Migraine headaches, depression
Medications: Sumatriptan PRN, sertraline 50mg daily
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 125/78, HR 82, RR 16, Temp 98.6°F
Physical Examination: Alert, oriented, photophobic, lying in dark room. Neurologic exam normal, no focal deficits, no meningeal signs. Left temporal tenderness.
Laboratory/Imaging: None indicated given typical presentation
ASSESSMENT Migraine headache without aura
PLAN Treatment: IV fluids 1L, sumatriptan 6mg SQ, metoclopramide 10mg IV, darkened room Medications: Sumatriptan 100mg tablets PRN, continue sertraline Instructions: Rest in dark quiet room, maintain regular sleep schedule, identify triggers
ICD-10:
G43.009 - Migraine without aura, not intractable, without status migrainosus
F32.9 - Major depressive disorder, single episode, unspecified

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
12. NEUROLEPTIC MALIGNANT SYNDROME
Patient: Michael Foster (Fictional), DOB: 09/03/1992
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 32-year-old male with schizophrenia presents with altered mental status, hyperthermia, and muscle rigidity for 24 hours. Caregivers report patient became increasingly confused and rigid after haloperidol dose was increased 1 week ago. Reports profuse sweating, unable to speak coherently. No recent infections or other medication changes.
Past Medical History: Schizophrenia, hypertension
Medications: Haloperidol 10mg daily (recently increased), amlodipine 5mg daily
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 180/100, HR 130, RR 26, Temp 104.2°F
Physical Examination: Altered mental status, lead-pipe rigidity throughout, profuse diaphoresis, tremor
Laboratory Results:
CBC: WBC 15.2 k/μL
BMP: Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (elevated)
CK: 8,500 U/L (markedly elevated)
LFTs: AST 210 U/L, ALT 185 U/L
ASSESSMENT Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
PLAN Immediate Treatment: Discontinue haloperidol, cooling measures, dantrolene 2.5mg/kg IV, bromocriptine 2.5mg PO TID Admission: ICU for hemodynamic monitoring and supportive care Monitoring: Fluid balance, renal function, temperature management

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
13. ALLERGIC REACTION/ANAPHYLAXIS
Patient: Lisa Anderson (Fictional), DOB: 12/18/1991
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 33-year-old female presents with generalized urticaria, facial swelling, and throat tightness 30 minutes after eating shrimp at restaurant. Reports immediate onset of itching, then facial swelling and difficulty swallowing. Denies previous reactions to shellfish but reports seasonal allergies. No difficulty breathing but feels throat closing.
Past Medical History: Seasonal allergies
Medications: Loratadine PRN
Allergies: Environmental allergies
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 95/60, HR 115, RR 22, Temp 98.6°F, O2 Sat 97% RA
Physical Examination: Facial angioedema, diffuse urticaria, mild inspiratory stridor, no wheezing
Laboratory Results: None obtained given clinical presentation
ASSESSMENT Anaphylaxis secondary to shellfish
PLAN Treatment: Epinephrine 0.3mg IM, methylprednisolone 125mg IV, diphenhydramine 50mg IV, famotidine 20mg IV, IV fluids Medications: EpiPen auto-injector x2, prednisone taper, antihistamines Instructions: Strict shellfish avoidance, carry EpiPen at all times, medical alert bracelet

ICD-10:
T78.05XA - Anaphylactic reaction due to shellfish, initial encounter
Z91.013 - Allergy to seafood

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
14. THYROID STORM
Patient: Helen Chang (Fictional), DOB: 04/08/1968
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 57-year-old female with known hyperthyroidism presents with palpitations, confusion, fever, and diarrhea for 12 hours. Patient stopped taking methimazole 1 week ago due to nausea. Reports rapid heart rate, profuse sweating, tremor, and altered mental status per family. Multiple loose stools, decreased oral intake.
Past Medical History: Graves' disease, atrial fibrillation
Medications: Methimazole 20mg daily (discontinued), warfarin 5mg daily
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 170/90, HR 160 (irregular), RR 24, Temp 103.8°F
Physical Examination: Altered mental status, tremor, diaphoresis, enlarged thyroid with bruit, irregular rhythm
Laboratory Results:
TSH: <0.01 mIU/L
Free T4: >7.0 ng/dL (markedly elevated)
Free T3: >20 pg/mL (markedly elevated)
CBC: WBC 12.8 k/μL
BMP: Normal
ASSESSMENT Thyroid storm (thyrotoxic crisis)
PLAN Treatment: Propranolol 80mg PO q6h, methimazole 20mg PO q8h, potassium iodide 5 drops PO q6h, hydrocortisone 300mg IV q8h Supportive Care: Cooling measures, IV fluids, electrolyte monitoring Admission: ICU for close monitoring

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
15. ALCOHOL WITHDRAWAL
Patient: James Wilson (Fictional), DOB: 11/22/1975
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 49-year-old male presents with tremors, anxiety, sweating, and nausea 36 hours after last alcohol consumption. Reports drinking daily for 20 years (approximately 12 beers daily), stopped due to illness. Experiences shaking hands, anxiety, difficulty sleeping, and poor appetite. Denies visual or auditory hallucinations, no seizure history.
Past Medical History: Alcohol use disorder, hypertension, GERD
Medications: Lisinopril 20mg daily, omeprazole 20mg daily
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 155/95, HR 105, RR 20, Temp 99.8°F
Physical Examination: Fine tremor of hands, diaphoresis, mild confusion, hyperreflexia, no focal neurologic deficits
Laboratory Results:
CBC: Hgb 11.2 g/dL (low), MCV 102 fL (elevated)
BMP: Normal
LFTs: AST 89 U/L, ALT 76 U/L (elevated)
Magnesium: 1.6 mg/dL (low)
ASSESSMENT Alcohol withdrawal syndrome, mild to moderate

PLAN Treatment: CIWA protocol, lorazepam 2mg PO q2h PRN (CIWA >8), thiamine 100mg IV/PO daily, folate 1mg daily, multivitamin Supportive Care: IV fluids, magnesium replacement Instructions: Alcohol cessation counseling, outpatient addiction treatment referral

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
16. COPD EXACERBATION
Patient: Robert Garcia (Fictional), DOB: 08/30/1955
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 69-year-old male with COPD presents with increased dyspnea, productive cough with purulent sputum, and decreased exercise tolerance for 4 days. Reports yellow-green sputum production, increased from baseline. Unable to walk to mailbox without stopping to rest. Using albuterol inhaler every 2 hours with minimal relief. No fever or chest pain.
Past Medical History: COPD (moderate), coronary artery disease, diabetes
Medications: Tiotropium daily, albuterol PRN, metformin 1000mg BID
Social History: 40 pack-year smoking history, quit 2 years ago
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 140/85, HR 88, RR 24, Temp 99.4°F, O2 Sat 88% RA, 94% on 2L NC
Physical Examination: Accessory muscle use, prolonged expiration, decreased breath sounds bilateral lower lobes, no wheeze
Laboratory Results:
ABG: pH 7.38, pCO2 48, pO2 58, HCO3 28
CBC: WBC 11.5 k/μL
Procalcitonin: 0.8 ng/mL
Imaging: Chest X-ray shows hyperinflation, no pneumonia
ASSESSMENT COPD exacerbation with acute respiratory failure
PLAN Treatment: Albuterol/ipratropium nebulizers q4h, prednisone 40mg daily x 5 days, azithromycin 500mg daily x 5 days Oxygen: 2L NC to maintain O2 sat 88-92% Instructions: Continue bronchodilators, smoking cessation maintenance, pulmonary rehabilitation

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
17. ADDISONIAN CRISIS
Patient: Nancy White (Fictional), DOB: 01/15/1980
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 45-year-old female with known Addison's disease presents with severe fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness for 2 days. Patient ran out of prednisone 3 days ago and was unable to refill prescription. Reports severe weakness, unable to get out of bed, multiple episodes of vomiting, abdominal pain. No fever, no diarrhea.
Past Medical History: Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease), hypothyroidism
Medications: Prednisone 7.5mg daily (missed 3 days), fludrocortisone 0.1mg daily, levothyroxine 75mcg daily
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 80/50, HR 120, RR 22, Temp 97.8°F
Physical Examination: Hyperpigmentation of skin and mucous membranes, severe dehydration, weakness, orthostatic hypotension
Laboratory Results:
BMP: Sodium 128 mEq/L, potassium 5.8 mEq/L, glucose 65 mg/dL
CBC: Normal
Random cortisol: <1.0 mcg/dL (very low)
ASSESSMENT Addisonian crisis (acute adrenal insufficiency)
PLAN Treatment: Hydrocortisone 100mg IV bolus, then 50mg IV q6h, aggressive fluid resuscitation with normal saline Monitoring: Electrolytes q6h, blood pressure, glucose Instructions: Never stop steroids abruptly, stress dosing education, medical alert bracelet

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
18. NECROTIZING FASCIITIS
Patient: Thomas Lee (Fictional), DOB: 03/07/1962
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 63-year-old diabetic male presents with rapidly spreading erythema, severe pain, and systemic illness following minor foot injury 48 hours ago. Reports stepped on nail, initially seemed minor. Developed severe pain out of proportion to injury, spreading redness up leg, fever, and feeling "very sick." Pain described as 10/10, constant.
Past Medical History: Diabetes type 2 (poorly controlled), peripheral neuropathy, hypertension
Medications: Metformin 1000mg BID, insulin glargine 40 units daily, lisinopril 20mg daily
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 85/55, HR 135, RR 28, Temp 102.6°F, O2 Sat 94% RA
Physical Examination: Dusky, necrotic-appearing skin with hemorrhagic bullae, crepitus palpable, severe systemic toxicity, altered mental status
Laboratory Results:
CBC: WBC 20.5 k/μL with bandemia
BMP: Glucose 385 mg/dL, creatinine 2.8 mg/dL, lactate 4.2 mmol/L
CRP: 285 mg/L (markedly elevated)
Imaging: CT shows gas within soft tissues, fascial plane involvement
ASSESSMENT Necrotizing fasciitis, right foot with septic shock
PLAN Emergency Treatment: Emergent surgical debridement, broad-spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin + piperacillin-tazobactam + clindamycin) Supportive Care: Aggressive fluid resuscitation, vasopressors, ICU admission Monitoring: Serial debridements likely needed, hyperbaric oxygen consideration

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
3. ACUTE APPENDICITIS
Patient: Jennifer Park (Fictional)
DOB: 04/22/1998
MRN: 456789123
Date of Service: May 22, 2025
Time of Arrival: 22:15
Time of Discharge: Post-operative day 1
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 27-year-old female presents with 18-hour history of abdominal pain that began periumbilically and migrated to right lower quadrant. Pain initially crampy, now constant and sharp, rated 8/10. Associated with nausea, vomiting (3 episodes), and low-grade fever. Reports decreased appetite and has not had bowel movement since yesterday.
Pain worsened with walking, coughing, or sudden movements. No urinary symptoms. Last menstrual period 2 weeks ago, regular cycles. Denies sexual activity. No similar episodes in past.
Past Medical History: None
Medications: None
Social History: Graduate student, denies tobacco/alcohol/drugs
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 118/72, HR 95, RR 18, Temp 100.8°F, O2 Sat 99% RA
General: Appears uncomfortable, guarding abdomen
Physical Examination:
Abdomen: McBurney's point tenderness, positive Rovsing's sign, positive psoas sign, no rebound initially, bowel sounds hypoactive
Pelvic: Normal external genitalia, no discharge
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm
Pulmonary: Clear bilaterally
Extremities: No edema
Laboratory Results:
CBC: WBC 12.8 k/μL with left shift, Hgb 12.4 g/dL
BMP: Normal
Urinalysis: Normal
Beta-hCG: Negative
CRP: 45 mg/L (elevated)
Imaging:
CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast: Appendiceal wall thickening, periappendiceal fat stranding, small amount free fluid
ASSESSMENT Acute appendicitis without complications
PLAN
Pre-operative Management:
NPO, IV fluids
Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone 1g IV + metronidazole 500mg IV
Pain control: Morphine 4mg IV PRN
Antiemetic: Ondansetron 4mg IV
Surgical Procedure: Laparoscopic appendectomy performed without complications Post-operative Course: Tolerated procedure well, advanced diet POD#1, discharged home
ICD-10:
K35.9 - Acute appendicitis, unspecified
R10.31 - Right lower quadrant pain

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
4. GUILLAIN-BARRÉ SYNDROME
Patient: Robert Kim (Fictional)
DOB: 11/28/1972
MRN: 789123456
Date of Service: May 22, 2025
Time of Arrival: 09:45
Time of Discharge: Admitted to Neuro ICU
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 52-year-old male presents with 3-day history of progressive weakness starting in bilateral legs, now affecting arms and face. Reports initial "tingling" in toes that progressed to inability to walk without assistance. Now reports difficulty lifting arms above head and mild difficulty swallowing.
Patient had upper respiratory infection with fever and cough 2 weeks ago that resolved. Denies back pain, bowel/bladder dysfunction, or sensory loss. Reports mild facial weakness noted this morning. No recent vaccinations or travel.
Past Medical History: Hypertension, diabetes type 2
Medications: Metformin 1000mg BID, lisinopril 20mg daily
Social History: Engineer, denies tobacco/alcohol/drugs
Allergies: NKDA
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 145/88, HR 72, RR 16, Temp 98.6°F, O2 Sat 98% RA
General: Alert, anxious, mild respiratory effort
Physical Examination:
Neurologic: 
Mental status: Alert, oriented x4
Cranial nerves: Mild bilateral facial weakness (VII), otherwise intact
Motor: Symmetric weakness - legs 2/5 proximally, 3/5 distally; arms 3/5 proximally, 4/5 distally
Reflexes: Absent throughout
Sensation: Intact to light touch, vibration, position
Coordination: Limited by weakness
Laboratory Results:
CBC: Normal
BMP: Glucose 165 mg/dL, otherwise normal
CK: 89 U/L (normal)
ESR: 15 mm/hr (normal)
Diagnostic Studies:
Lumbar puncture: Protein 85 mg/dL (elevated), glucose 65 mg/dL, cell count <5 WBCs
Nerve conduction studies: Demyelinating pattern with conduction blocks
Pulmonary function: FVC 65% predicted
ASSESSMENT Guillain-Barré syndrome (AIDP variant)
PLAN
Acute Treatment:
IVIG: 0.4g/kg/day x 5 days
Supportive care: DVT prophylaxis, pulmonary toilet
Monitoring: Serial pulmonary function tests, cardiac monitoring
Admission Orders:
Neuro ICU for respiratory monitoring
Physical therapy evaluation
Occupational therapy evaluation
Speech therapy evaluation
Neurology consultation
Medications:
Gabapentin 300mg - Three times daily for neuropathic pain
Enoxaparin 40mg - Daily subcutaneous for DVT prophylaxis
Pantoprazole 40mg - Daily for GI protection

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
6. ASTHMA EXACERBATION
Patient: Timothy Johnson (Fictional)
DOB: 03/14/2010
MRN: 147258369
Date of Service: May 22, 2025
Time of Arrival: 19:30
Time of Discharge: 23:15
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 15-year-old male presents with worsening shortness of breath, wheezing, and cough for 2 days. Patient reports increased albuterol inhaler use (every 2 hours) without significant relief. Mother reports child has been unable to speak in full sentences and has difficulty sleeping due to cough and dyspnea.
Symptoms began after spending time outdoors during high pollen day. Patient reports chest tightness and feeling "like I can't get enough air." No fever, no productive cough, no chest pain. Last hospitalization for asthma was 2 years ago.
Past Medical History: Asthma (moderate persistent), allergic rhinitis
Medications: Albuterol inhaler PRN, fluticasone inhaler daily, loratadine PRN
Social History: High school student, no tobacco exposure
Allergies: Environmental allergies (pollen, dust mites)
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 110/65, HR 115, RR 28, Temp 98.6°F, O2 Sat 91% RA, 97% on 3L NC
General: Mild respiratory distress, using accessory muscles
Physical Examination:
Pulmonary: Diffuse expiratory wheeze, prolonged expiration, decreased air movement bilaterally
Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, regular rhythm
HEENT: No nasal flaring, no stridor
Extremities: No cyanosis or clubbing
Laboratory Results:
ABG: pH 7.42, pCO2 38, pO2 65, HCO3 24, O2 sat 91%
Imaging:
Chest X-ray: Hyperinflation, no pneumothorax, no infiltrates
ASSESSMENT Moderate asthma exacerbation with hypoxemia
PLAN
Emergency Department Treatment:
Bronchodilators: Albuterol/ipratropium nebulizers every 20 minutes x 3
Systemic steroids: Prednisolone 40mg PO
Oxygen therapy: Nasal cannula to maintain O2 sat >95%
Discharge Medications:
Prednisolone 40mg - Daily for 5 days
Albuterol inhaler - 2 puffs every 4-6 hours as needed
Fluticasone inhaler - 2 puffs twice daily (continue controller)

Please respond with the correct ED Short List code.

Casenote:
8. URINARY TRACT INFECTION
Patient: Dorothy Miller (Fictional)
DOB: 07/09/1952
MRN: 963852741
Date of Service: May 22, 2025
Time of Arrival: 14:30
Time of Discharge: 17:45
SOAP NOTE
SUBJECTIVE 72-year-old female presents with 3-day history of dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic discomfort. Reports burning sensation with urination and feeling of incomplete bladder emptying. Denies fever, chills, flank pain, or nausea/vomiting.
Patient reports urinating every 1-2 hours with small volumes. Notes urine appears cloudy and has strong odor. No hematuria noted. Similar episodes in past that responded well to antibiotics.
Past Medical History: Diabetes type 2, osteoporosis, recurrent UTIs
Medications: Metformin 1000mg BID, alendronate 70mg weekly, calcium/vitamin D
Social History: Retired teacher, lives alone, denies tobacco/alcohol
Allergies: Sulfa drugs (rash)
OBJECTIVE Vital Signs: BP 142/84, HR 78, RR 16, Temp 98.8°F, O2 Sat 99% RA
General: Alert, oriented, appears comfortable
Physical Examination:
Abdomen: Suprapubic tenderness, no CVA tenderness, no masses
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm
Pulmonary: Clear bilaterally
Extremities: No edema
Neurologic: Intact
Laboratory Results:
Urinalysis: 
Color: Yellow, cloudy
Specific gravity: 1.025
Protein: Trace
Glucose: Negative
Ketones: Negative
Blood: 1+
Nitrites: Positive
Leukocyte esterase: 3+
WBCs: >50/hpf
RBCs: 5-10/hpf

- Recommended cardiology consultation if chest pain persists or worsens.
3. **Red Flags:**
- Return to the Emergency Department immediately if experiencing chest pain that is severe, persistent, or associated with symptoms such as shortness of breath, dizziness, or fainting.
